FACILITY DESCRIPTION
The Teague Gas Plant is owned and operated by Hilcorp Energy Company.  The plant is located near Teague, Texas in Freestone County, Texas.  The plant is designed to process approximately 330MMscf/d of naturally occurring natural gas.  
Hilcorp employs approximately 10 full time employees and contractors at the facility.   

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
It is the policy of Hilcorp Energy Company to conduct business in a responsible and ethical manner that protects the safety and health of employees and the public as well as protecting the environment. The Teague Plant Emergency Action Plan covers procedures for reporting fires or other emergencies, emergency evacuation and exit routes, procedures for employees who remain to operate critical plant operations prior to evacuation, accounting for personnel, rescue and medical duties, and contact information for employees responsible for plan implementation and who can provide more information to other employees about the plan.  
The Emergency Action Plan is coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and the facility coordinates routine drills and table top exercises with local emergency response personnel.   

PROCESS DESCRIPTION
Process 1  Propane Refrigeration
The facility employs a gas chilling process utilizing a propane refrigeration system to supply cooling in the Gas Chiller as described in Process 2.  Threshold quantities of regulated flammable substances are present at the facility in Process 1, but no threshold quantities of regulated toxic substances are present at the facility.   Refrigerant grade propane flows from the Refrigerant Accumulator to the Refrigerant Economizer where vapors flash off at approximately 45psig.  These vapors are routed to an interstage port on the refrigeration compressor.  The propane liquid flows on level control to the inlet gas chiller where it is vaporized at approximately -35 deg. F.  The vaporizing propane provides cool

ing for the treated gas.  The propane vapors are then routed to a suction scrubber where any liquids are removed via level control.  The vapors from the suction scrubber are compressed to approximately 240psig in three of four, 1250 Hp motor driven screw compressors.  The vapor is then condensed at 120 deg. F in the refrigerant condenser and flows back to the refrigerant accumulator.  Bulk propane refrigerant for make-up is stored in the Refrigerant Storage tank which has a maximum allowable operating pressure of 250psig and a capacity of 12,000 gallons.  
Process 2 - Natural Gas Processing
The Teague Plant takes raw natural gas from the Hilcorp operated Trend Gathering System where the gas undergoes a variety of processes to deliver marketable Natural Gas, Natural Gas Liquids, and Natural Gas Condensate to market.   Threshold quantities of regulated flammable substances are present at the facility in Process 2, but no threshold quantities of regulated toxic substances are present at the facility. 
Produced natural gas and liquids enter the plant at an approximate design rate of 330MMCFD and at approximately 965psig. The gas flows through an MDEA (Methyl Diethanolamine) amine unit that removes CO2 and H2S from the gas stream.  Rich amine from the amine contactor is flashed in a flash vessel and the flash gas is be sent to the plants fuel system to be used as fuel for various fired processes in the facility. The rich amine liquid flows to the amine regeneration unit where the CO2 and H2S are driven off with heat from the facilitys hot oil system. The lean amine is then cooled and sent back to the amine contactor.  The resultant regenerator overhead vapor containing H2S and CO2 is sent to a caustic contact tower where a caustic solution (typically sodium hydroxide) absorbs the H2S and flows to a closed loop H2S biological treatment unit (Paques Plant). The H2S in the caustic stream will be aerobically reduced with specialized bacteria and the lean caustic will retur

n to the caustic contact tower and the CO2 is sent to a flare. Spent biomass along with products of digestion from the Paques plant are disposed of.  
Wet, treated gas flows to a Gas Chiller where it is cooled to a design temperature of -32 deg. F for hydrocarbon liquid (NGL) recovery and to meet gas pipeline specifications.  Ethylene Glycol (EG) is injected into the wet gas stream upstream of the gas chiller to dehydrate the gas and prevent freezing in the chiller or associated piping/equipment.  The treated gas and EG mixture leaves the chiller and enters the Glycol Cold Separator where EG/Water (rich EG), liquid hydrocarbons (NGLs) and the dry gas are separated.  The treated, dry gas is then sent to residue compression where pressure is increased to deliver the gas to a downstream pipeline.  Cooling is achieved through a propane refrigeration system (described in Process 2).  
The rich EG is regenerated in an Ethylene Glycol Regeneration system where the water is driven off of the glycol with heat and the lean EG is recycled back to be injected into the treated gas stream.  Process heat is provided through a hot oil system.  
NGLs extracted from the treated gas stream in the Glycol Cold Separator are then stabilized and sent to atmospheric storage tanks to be trucked for sales.  The stabilization process involves driving off the lighter end vapors using heat from the hot oil system.  The overhead vapors are compressed and recycled back to the plant inlet.  

REGULATED SUBSTANCES ABOVE THRESHOLD QUANTITIES AT TEAGUE PLANT
The Teague Plant maintains threshold quantities of refrigerant grade propane in Process 1.  The facility also maintains threshold quantities of flammable, naturally occurring hydrocarbon mixtures of methane, ethane, propane, butane, and pentane in Process 2.  
Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is present in the gas stream, but not at the threshold quantity per § 68.130.  

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS
Process 1 - 
The Worst-Case Scenario (WCS) for P

rocess 1 is a loss of containment of the Refrigerant Storage Tank (V-416) resulting in the release of the entire inventory of the vessel (50,400lbs) resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The calculated maximum distance to the 1 psi overpressure endpoint is 0.3 miles.  This calculated endpoint is beyond the facility boundary, but no public receptors are within that calculated distance.  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent such releases and to manage their consequences, no credit for engineering controls, administrative controls, or passive mitigation measures were considered in evaluating this WCS.  
Process 2 - 
The Worst-Case Scenario (WCS) for Process 2 is a loss of containment of the Glycol Cold Separator (V-411) resulting in the release of the entire inventory of the vessel (38,500lbs) resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The calculated maximum distance to the 1 psi overpressure endpoint is 0.3 miles.  This calculated endpoint is beyond the facility boundary, but no public receptors are within that calculated distance.  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent such releases and to manage their consequences, no credit for engineering controls, administrative controls, or passive mitigation measures were considered in evaluating this WCS.  

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The Teague Plant is covered under OSHAs Process Safety Management standard, 29 CFR 1910.119 and has programs and systems in place to comply with all aspects of the PSM standard.  
Hilcorp encourages employees to participate in all aspects of Process Safety Management and accident prevention.  As such, facility employees have access to all information created as part of the facility Process Safety Management and accident prevention programs. 
The processes are controlled and monitored using process instruments, trained personnel, and protective systems (e.g. distributive control systems, automated detection, emergency shutdown systems, closed blowdown sy

stems, pressure relief valves, pressure control valves, remotely located flare systems, etc.).
The Teague Plant employs a comprehensive hazard evaluation program (Process Hazard Analysis) to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.
The Teague Plant maintains written operating procedures that address various modes of process operations such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, and (5) normal shutdown. 
To complement the written procedures for process operations, the facility has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the Teague Plant.
The facility uses Management of change processes to control and track Facility changes. 
Mechanical Integrity programs including on-line equipment testing (e.g. ultrasonic thickness testing, radiographic examination, etc.), equipment preventative maintenance, and regularly scheduled internal equipment inspection and repair.

THE FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
In the past 5 years, there have been no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage that may have resulted from any activities or incidents at the Teague Gas Plant.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE
The Teague Gas Plant maintains a written Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The EAP consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The EAP also covers the sequential steps of addressing a potential fire, spill, and tornado

threats.  The EAP addresses the responsibilities of facility personnel to respond to emergencies, outlines the network of communication, and provides key internal and external contact information.   The Emergency Action Plan is updated routinely and as necessary to account for changes in personnel and in the process.    The overall Emergency Action Plan for the Teague Plant is coordinated with the Freestone Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). The facility has around-the-clock communications capability with the LEPC officials.  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident.
